commands.name: pwd
commands.description: Print the absolute path of the current working directory

L.name: Logical
L.description: The logical current directory path, respecting symbolic links and environment variables. Shows the path as referenced, even if through symlinks

P.name: Physical
P.description: The actual physical path, resolving all symbolic links. Shows the real location in the filesystem

help.name: help
help.description: Display help information about pwd command usage and options

L.explanation: Shows logical path even when directory is a symbolic link.

P.explanation: Shows physical path after resolving symbolic links.

help.output: INFORMATION ABOUT HOW TO USE PWD

commands.name: ls
commands.description: List directory contents

a.name: all
a.description: List all entries, including entries starting with .

A.name: almost-all
A.description: List all entries, including entries starting with ., except for . and ..

b.name: escape
b.description: List entries. Print the \ character for spaces, tabs and line breaks

B.name: ignore-backups
B.description: Do not list backup entries (entries ending with ~)

c.name: ctime
c.description: ls -c sorts files by ctime (change time), showing newest files first

C.name: format-column
C.description: List entries in columns (Note: This is the default behaviour in the terminal. However, when output is written to files, this command will change how the output is written)

d.name: directory
d.description: List the directory itself, not the contents of the directory

f.name: unsorted
f.description: Do not sort. It enables the -a flag and disables the -l, -o, -g flags

F.name: classify
F.description:
Append indicator to entries
No character means regular file
- means Directory
* means Executable file
@ means Symbolic link (shortcut to another file)
= – Socket (special file for inter-process communication)
| – Named pipe (FIFO)
> – Door (Solaris-specific)

g.name: group-only
g.description: Use a long listing format. Display the permissions, number of links, group owner, file size, last modification date and time, file name

H.name: dereference-command-line
H.description: Go into a symlink directory and use this flag. It will list the contents in the directory it is linked to

i.name: inode
i.description: Print the index number of each item

I.name: ignore
I.description: Do not list entries whose names match given pattern

k.name: kibibytes
k.description: Default to 1024-byte blocks (kilobytes) for disk usage

l.name: long
l.description: Use a long listing format. Display the permissions, number of links, user owner, group owner, file size, last modification date and time, file name

L.name: dereference
L.description: When showing file information for a symbolic link, show information for the file the link references rather than for the link itself

m.name: comma
m.description: Display entries as a comma separated list of entries

n.name: numeric-uid-gid
n.description: Use a long listing format. Display the permissions, number of links, numeric user owner, group owner ID, file size, last modification date and time, file name

N.name: literal
N.description: Print raw entry names (don't treat certain characters specially)

o.name: omit-group
o.description: Use a long listing format. Display the permissions, number of links, user owner, file size, last modification date and time, file name

p.name: file-type
p.description: Append / indicator to directories

Q.name: quote-name
Q.description: Enclose entry names in double quotes

s.name: size
s.description: Print the allocated size of each file, in blocks

S.name: sort-size
S.description: Sort by file size, largest first

t.name: sort-time
t.description: Sort by modification time, newest first

u.name: atime
u.description: With -lt: sort by, and show, access time. With -l: show access time and sort by name

U.name: unsorted
U.description: Do not sort; list entries in directory order

v.name: sort-version
v.description: Natural sort of (version) numbers within text

help.name: help
help.description: Display help information about ls command usage and options

full-time.name: full-time
full-time.description: Use a long listing format. Display the permissions, number of links, user owner, group owner, file size, last modification date and full time, file name

si.name: si
si.description: Print human readable sizes but use powers of 1000 instead of 1024

sort.name: sort
sort.description: Specify sort order (none, size, time, version, extension)

time.name: time
time.description: Specify which timestamp to use (atime, access, use, ctime, status)

time-style.name: time-style
time-style.description: Specify time/date format (full-iso, long-iso, iso, locale, etc.)

basic.explanation: Lists contents of current directory in simple format

l.output:
drwxr-xr-x 2 user group 4096 Jan 1 12:00 directory1
-rw-r--r-- 1 user group  1024 Jan 1 12:00 file1.txt
l.explanation: Shows detailed information including permissions, owner, group, size, and modification time

a.explanation: Shows all files including hidden ones (starting with .)

la.output:
drwxr-xr-x 5 user group 4096 Jan 1 12:00 .
drwxr-xr-x 3 user group 4096 Jan 1 11:00 ..
-rw-r--r-- 1 user group    0 Jan 1 12:00 .hidden_file
-rw-r--r-- 1 user group 1024 Jan 1 12:00 file1.txt
la.explanation: Combines long format with showing all files

lh.output:
drwxr-xr-x 2 user group 4.0K Jan 1 12:00 directory1
-rw-r--r-- 1 user group 1.0K Jan 1 12:00 file1.txt
lh.explanation: Shows human-readable sizes (KB, MB, etc.) in long format

R.explanation: Recursively lists all files in current directory and all subdirectories

t.explanation: Sorts files by modification time, newest first

S.output:
-rw-r--r-- 1 user group 2048 Jan 1 12:00 file2.txt
-rw-r--r-- 1 user group 1024 Jan 1 12:00 file1.txt
drwxr-xr-x 2 user group 4096 Jan 1 12:00 directory1
S.explanation: Sorts files by size, largest first

help.output: INFORMATION ABOUT HOW TO USE LS

commands.name: cd
commands.description: Change the current working directory

L.name: logical
L.description: Follow symbolic links. Resolve '..' components before symbolic links (default behavior in most shells)

P.name: physical
P.description: Use physical directory structure without following symbolic links. Resolve '..' after symbolic links

help.name: help
help.description: Display help information about cd command usage

home.explanation: Changes to the user's home directory (~)

relative.explanation: Changes to Documents subdirectory of current directory

parent.explanation: Moves up one directory level to parent directory

previous.explanation: Changes to previous working directory and prints its path

P.explanation: Changes to the actual physical directory instead of following symbolic links

L.explanation: Follows symbolic links when changing directory (default behavior)

commands.name: mkdir
commands.description: Create directories

p.name: parents
p.description: Create parent directories as needed; no error if existing

m.name: mode
m.description: Set file mode (permissions) for created directories

v.name: verbose
v.description: Print a message for each created directory

help.name: help
help.description: Display help information about mkdir command usage and options

basic.explanation: Creates a single directory named 'new_folder' in the current location

p.explanation: Creates the entire directory path. If 'projects' or '2024' don't exist, they are created automatically.

m.explanation: Creates a directory with specific permissions (rwxr-x--- in this example)

v.explanation: Verbose output confirms the directory creation

help.output: INFORMATION ABOUT HOW TO USE MKDIR

commands.name: rmdir
commands.description: Remove empty directories

ignore-fail-on-non-empty.name: ignore-fail-on-non-empty
ignore-fail-on-non-empty.description: Ignore each failure that is solely because a directory is non-empty

p.name: parents
p.description: Remove DIRECTORY and its ancestors; e.g., 'rmdir -p a/b/c' is similar to 'rmdir a/b/c a/b a'

v.name: verbose
v.description: Output a diagnostic for every directory processed

help.name: help
help.description: Display help information about rmdir command usage

basic.explanation: Removes the empty directory named 'mydir' from the current location. Fails if the directory is not empty.

p.explanation: Removes the directory path recursively. It will remove 'components', then 'src', then 'project', provided each directory becomes empty after the removal. Useful for cleaning up an empty directory tree.

v.explanation: Verbose mode outputs a message confirming which directory is being removed.

pv.output:
rmdir: removing directory, 'a/b/c'
rmdir: removing directory, 'a/b'
rmdir: removing directory, 'a'
pv.explanation: Combines verbose output with parent removal, showing each step of the recursive directory removal.

ignore-fail-on-non-empty.output: rmdir: failed to remove 'dir2': Directory not empty
ignore-fail-on-non-empty.explanation: Attempts to remove multiple directories. It will skip errors for directories that are not empty (like 'dir2') and continue to try removing the others (like 'dir1' and 'dir3').

commands.name: cp
commands.description: Copy files and directories

i.name: interactive
i.description: Prompt before overwriting existing files

n.name: no-clobber
n.description: Do not overwrite an existing file

a.name: archive
a.description: Preserve all file attributes, including permissions, timestamps, and symbolic links

p.name: preserve
p.description: Preserve file attributes like mode, ownership, and timestamps

v.name: verbose
v.description: Print the name of each file before copying

u.name: update
u.description: Copy only when the source file is newer than the destination file or when the destination file is missing

l.name: link
l.description: Create hard links instead of copying

s.name: symbolic-link
s.description: Create symbolic links instead of copying

b.name: backup
b.description: Make a backup of each existing destination file

t.name: target-directory
t.description: Copy all source arguments into the specified directory

help.name: help
help.description: Display help information about cp command usage and options

basic.explanation: Copies file1.txt to file2.txt in the current directory

r.explanation: Recursively copies directory dir1 and its contents to dir2

i.explanation: Prompts before overwriting if destination.txt already exists

v.explanation: Verbose output shows what is being copied

a.explanation: Creates an exact archive copy preserving all attributes

u.explanation: Only copies text files that are newer than existing ones in /backup/

multiple.explanation: Copies multiple files to a directory

commands.name: mv
commands.description: Move or rename files and directories

i.name: interactive
i.description: Prompt before overwriting existing files

n.name: no-clobber
n.description: Do not overwrite an existing file

v.name: verbose
v.description: Print the name of each file before moving

b.name: backup
b.description: Make a backup of each existing destination file

u.name: update
u.description: Move only when the source file is newer than the destination file or when the destination file is missing

t.name: target-directory
t.description: Move all source arguments into the specified directory

help.name: help
help.description: Display help information about mv command usage and options

basic_rename.explanation: Renames oldname.txt to newname.txt in the current directory

basic_move.explanation: Moves file.txt to the specified directory

i.explanation: Prompts before overwriting if destination.txt already exists

v.explanation: Verbose output shows what is being moved

multiple.explanation: Moves multiple files to a directory

rename_dir.explanation: Renames a directory from old_dir to new_dir

commands.name: rm
commands.description: Remove files or directories

i.name: interactive
i.description: Prompt before every removal

r.name: recursive
r.description: Remove directories and their contents recursively

f.name: force
f.description: Ignore nonexistent files and arguments, never prompt

v.name: verbose
v.description: Print a message for each removed file

d.name: dir
d.description: Remove empty directories

help.name: help
help.description: Display help information about rm command usage and options

basic.explanation: Removes file.txt from the current directory

r.explanation: Recursively removes directory and all its contents

i.explanation: Prompts for confirmation before removing each .txt file

rf.explanation: Forcefully and recursively removes directory without prompting (USE WITH CAUTION). WARNING: rm -rf / or rm -rf ~ are EXTREMELY DANGEROUS commands that can wipe your entire system or home directory. Always double-check the path before using rm with -r and -f flags.

v.explanation: Verbose output shows what was removed

pattern.explanation: Removes all files with .tmp extension in current directory

commands.name: touch
commands.description: Change file timestamps (access and modification times). Creates empty files if they don't exist.

c.name: no-create
c.description: Do not create any files if they don't exist

r.name: reference
r.description: Use the timestamp of the reference file instead of current time

t.name: time
t.description: Use specified time instead of current time (format: [[CC]YY]MMDDhhmm[.ss])

d.name: date
d.description: Use specified date string instead of current time

help.name: help
help.description: Display help information about touch command usage and options

basic_create.explanation: Creates an empty file named newfile.txt if it doesn't exist, or updates its timestamp if it does

multiple.explanation: Creates or updates timestamps for multiple files

c.explanation: Updates timestamp of existing.txt only if it exists (won't create it)

r.explanation: Sets target.txt's timestamp to match source.txt's timestamp

t.explanation: Sets file.txt's timestamp to December 25, 2023 at 12:00:00

d.explanation: Sets file.txt's timestamp to 2 days ago

a.explanation: Updates only the access time of file.txt to current time

m.explanation: Updates only the modification time of file.txt to current time

commands.name: cat
commands.description: Concatenate and display the entire contents of files. Primarily used to read, combine, and create files.

A.name: show-all
A.description: Equivalent to -vET. Show non-printing characters, display $ at end of each line, and show tabs as ^I.

b.name: number-nonblank
b.description: Number all non-empty output lines, starting at 1.

e.name: show-ends
e.description: Equivalent to -vE. Show non-printing characters and display $ at end of each line.

E.name: show-ends
E.description: Display $ at the end of each line.

n.name: number
n.description: Number all output lines, starting at 1.

s.name: squeeze-blank
s.description: Suppress repeated empty output lines. Multiple consecutive blank lines are replaced with one.

t.name: show-tabs
t.description: Equivalent to -vT. Show non-printing characters and display tabs as ^I.

v.name: show-nonprinting
v.description: Use ^ and M- notation, except for LFD and TAB. Display non-printing characters.

basic.output:
This is line one.
This is line two.
basic.explanation: Displays the entire content of 'file.txt' to the terminal.

n.output:
1  This is line one.
2  This is line two.
n.explanation: Displays the file with line numbers for all lines.

b.output:
1  This is line one.

2  This is line two.
b.explanation: Displays the file with line numbers only for non-blank lines.

E.output:
This is line one.$
This is line two.$
E.explanation: Makes the end of each line visible with a $ character.

multiple_files.output:
Content from file1.
Content from file2.
multiple_files.explanation: Concatenates and displays the contents of multiple files in sequence.

create_file.explanation: Creates 'newfile.txt'. Type input, then press Ctrl+D to save and exit.

append_file.explanation: Appends typed input to the end of 'existing.txt'. Press Ctrl+D to finish.

combine_files.explanation: Combines 'part1.txt' and 'part2.txt' and saves the result into a new file 'whole.txt'.

commands.name: less
commands.description: A powerful, interactive terminal pager for viewing file contents one screenful at a time. Allows forward and backward navigation.

e.name: quit-at-eof
e.description: Causes less to automatically exit the second time it reaches end-of-file. Default is to require 'q' to quit.

f.name: force-open
f.description: Forces non-regular files (directories, device files) to be opened.

g.name: highlight-search
g.description: Highlights only the string that matched the last search command, not all matches.

i.name: ignore-case
i.description: Causes searches to ignore case, unless the search pattern contains uppercase letters.

N.name: line-numbers
N.description: Displays a line number at the beginning of each line.

r.name: raw-control-chars
r.description: Causes 'raw' control characters to be displayed. Useful for viewing output containing ANSI color codes.

s.name: squeeze-blank-lines
s.description: Causes consecutive blank lines to be squeezed into a single blank line.

S.name: chop-long-lines
S.description: Causes lines longer than the screen width to be chopped (truncated) rather than wrapped.

X.name: no-init
X.description: Disables sending the termcap initialization and deinitialization strings to the terminal. Useful if content should remain on screen after quitting.

basic.explanation: Opens 'longfile.txt' in the less viewer. You can navigate with arrow keys, Page Up/Down.

N.explanation: Views the file with line numbers displayed.

i_Search.explanation: Opens 'logfile.txt' and performs an initial case-insensitive search for the string 'error'.

search_forward.explanation: Search forward for 'pattern'. Press 'n' for next match, 'N' for previous.

goto_line.explanation: Go to line 50. '1g' goes to start, 'G' goes to end.

commands.name: more
commands.description: A basic terminal pager for viewing file contents one screen at a time. Allows only forward navigation. (Note: 'less' is more powerful and generally preferred).

d.name: prompt
d.description: Displays '[Press space to continue, 'q' to quit.]' and displays '[Press 'h' for instructions.]' instead of ringing the bell when an illegal key is pressed.

f.name: count-lines
f.description: Count logical lines, rather than screen lines. Prevents long lines from causing wrapping/paging issues.

l.name: no-pause
l.description: Do not pause after any line containing a ^L (form feed).

p.name: clear
p.description: Do not scroll. Instead, clear the whole screen and then display the text.

c.name: paint
c.description: Do not scroll. Instead, repaint each line from the top, avoiding scrolling artifacts.

s.name: squeeze
s.description: Squeeze multiple blank lines into one.

u.name: no-underline
u.description: Suppress underline formatting.

+/.name: search-pattern
+/.description: Start two lines before the line containing the specified pattern.

basic.explanation: Opens 'longfile.txt'. Displays '--More--(XX%)' at the bottom. Press Space to page forward, Enter for one line. Cannot go back.

d.explanation: Provides a clearer prompt for the user.

+10.explanation: Starts viewing the file from line 10.

+/error.explanation: Starts viewing two lines before the first occurrence of the word 'error'.

commands.name: head
commands.description: Outputs the first part (beginning) of files. Default is 10 lines.

c.name: bytes
c.description: Print the first NUM bytes of each file. Can use suffixes like K, M, G.

n.name: lines
n.description: Print the first NUM lines of each file (instead of the default 10).

q.name: quiet
q.description: Never print headers giving file names. (Default when viewing one file).

v.name: verbose
v.description: Always print headers giving file names.

n.explanation: Displays only the first 5 lines of the file.

c.output: This is the first 50 bytes, includin
c.explanation: Displays the first 50 bytes (characters) of the file.

multiple_files.output:
==> file1.txt <==
Line1A
Line2A
Line3A

==> file2.txt <==
Line1B
Line2B
Line3B
multiple_files.explanation: Displays the first 3 lines of each specified file, with headers.

commands.name: tail
commands.description: Outputs the last part (end) of files. Extremely useful for monitoring log files. Default is 10 lines.

c.name: bytes
c.description: Output the last NUM bytes of each file. Can use suffixes like K, M, G.

n.name: lines
n.description: Output the last NUM lines of each file (instead of the default 10).

f.name: follow
f.description: Output appended data as the file grows. This is the primary way to follow log files in real-time.

F.name: follow-retry
F.description: Like -f, but also keeps trying to reopen the file if it becomes inaccessible (e.g., due to log rotation). Better for production monitoring.

q.name: quiet
q.description: Never output headers giving file names.

v.name: verbose
v.description: Always output headers giving file names.

n.explanation: Displays only the last 5 lines of the file.

f.explanation: Displays the last 10 lines of 'application.log' and then continues to output new lines as they are written to the file. Press Ctrl+C to stop.

F.explanation: Like -f, but robust against log rotation. If the file is renamed and a new one created, tail will continue following the new file.

c.explanation: Displays the last 1 kilobyte (1024 bytes) of the binary file.

multiple_files.explanation: Displays the last 2 lines of each log file.

commands.name: nano
commands.description: A simple, user-friendly command-line text editor. Easy for beginners as it displays common shortcuts at the bottom of the screen.

A.name: smarthome
A.description: Enable 'smart home' behavior. Home key takes cursor to first non-whitespace character of line, then to start of line.

B.name: backup
B.description: When saving a file, back up the previous version to 'filename~'.

i.name: autoindent
i.description: Automatically indent new lines to the same level as the previous line.

k.name: cut-from-cursor
k.description: Enable 'cut from cursor to end of line' feature.

l.name: nofollow
l.description: Don't follow symbolic links; overwrite the link itself.

m.name: mouse
m.description: Enable mouse support for positioning the cursor.

v.name: view
v.description: View mode (read-only). Disables editing.

basic.explanation: Opens 'myfile.txt' for editing. If it doesn't exist, it starts a new buffer with that name.

v.explanation: Opens the system file '/etc/fstab' in read-only view mode to prevent accidental changes.

B.explanation: Edits 'config.cfg'. When saved, the old version will be automatically backed up as 'config.cfg~'.

mw.explanation: Opens 'script.py' with mouse support enabled (-m) and line wrapping disabled (-w).

save.explanation: Write Out (Save). Press Enter to confirm filename.

exit.explanation: Exit nano. You will be prompted to save if buffer is modified.

cut_line.explanation: Cut the current line (or marked region).

search.explanation: Search for text within the file.

go_to_line.explanation: Go to a specific line and column number.

commands.name: chmod
commands.description: Change file mode bits (permissions) for files and directories

v.name: verbose
v.description: Output a diagnostic for every file processed

c.name: changes
c.description: Like verbose but report only when a change is made

basic.explanation: Sets permissions to rwxr-xr-x (user: read, write, execute; group/others: read, execute)

symbolic.explanation: Adds execute permission for user, removes write for group, sets others to read-only

recursive.explanation: Recursively sets all files in directory to rw-r--r--

commands.name: chown
commands.description: Change file owner and group

R.name: recursive
R.description: Operate on files and directories recursively

v.name: verbose
v.description: Output a diagnostic for every file processed

c.name: changes
c.description: Like verbose but report only when a change is made

from.name: from
from.description: Change the owner and/or group only if current owner/group matches specified

owner_group.explanation: Changes owner to 'john' and group to 'developers'

recursive.explanation: Recursively changes ownership of web directory

commands.name: chgrp
commands.description: Change group ownership of files and directories

R.name: recursive
R.description: Operate on files and directories recursively

v.name: verbose
v.description: Output a diagnostic for every file processed

c.name: changes
c.description: Like verbose but report only when a change is made

recursive.explanation: Recursively changes group ownership of web directory

reference.explanation: Sets target.txt's group to match source.txt's group

commands.name: find
commands.description: Search for files in a directory hierarchy

name.name: name
name.description: Search for files with specific name pattern

type.name: type
type.description: Search for specific file type (f=file, d=directory, l=symlink)

mtime.name: modified-time
mtime.description: Find files modified N days ago

modified.explanation: Finds files modified in the last 7 days

commands.name: grep
commands.description: Print lines matching a pattern

i.name: ignore-case
i.description: Ignore case distinctions

r.name: recursive
r.description: Read all files under each directory, recursively

v.name: invert-match
v.description: Select non-matching lines

n.name: line-number
n.description: Print line numbers with output lines

l.name: files-with-matches
l.description: Print only names of files with matching lines

c.name: count
c.description: Print only a count of matching lines per file

E.name: extended-regexp
E.description: Interpret PATTERN as an extended regular expression

w.name: word-regexp
w.description: Select only lines containing matches that form whole words

recursive.explanation: Recursively searches for 'TODO' in project directory

with_line_numbers.explanation: Shows line numbers with matching lines

commands.name: locate
commands.description: Find files by name using pre-built database

i.name: ignore-case
i.description: Ignore case distinctions when matching patterns

c.name: count
c.description: Only print number of found entries

l.name: limit
l.description: Limit output to specified number of entries

r.name: regexp
r.description: Use basic regexp for pattern matching

basic.explanation: Finds httpd.conf file quickly using database

case_insensitive.explanation: Finds README files regardless of case

commands.name: which
commands.description: Locate a command and show its path

a.name: all
a.description: Print all matching executables in PATH, not just the first

all.explanation: Shows all java executables in PATH

commands.name: whereis
commands.description: Locate binary, source, and manual page files for a command

s.name: sources
s.description: Search only for sources

basic.explanation: Shows binary and man page locations for ls

binary_only.explanation: Shows only binary location for gcc

man_page_only.explanation: Shows only man page location for grep

commands.name: uname
commands.description: Print system information

s.name: kernel-name
s.description: Print the kernel name

n.name: node-name
n.description: Print the network node hostname

v.name: kernel-version
v.description: Print the kernel version

p.name: processor
p.description: Print the processor type

all.output: Linux server1 5.4.0-42-generic #46-Ubuntu SMP Fri Jul 10 00:24:02 UTC 2020 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

commands.name: df
commands.description: Report file system disk space usage

h.name: human-readable
h.description: Print sizes in human readable format (e.g., 1K, 234M, 2G)

H.name: si
H.description: Print sizes in powers of 1000 (e.g., 1K = 1000 bytes)

i.name: inodes
i.description: List inode information instead of block usage

l.name: local
l.description: Limit listing to local file systems

human.output:
Filesystem      Size  Used Avail Use% Mounted on
devtmpfs        3.9G     0  3.9G   0% /dev
/dev/sda1        50G   30G   17G  64% /
human.explanation: Shows disk usage in human readable format

with_type.output:
Filesystem     Type      Size  Used Avail Use% Mounted on
devtmpfs       devtmpfs  3.9G     0  3.9G   0% /dev
/dev/sda1      ext4       50G   30G   17G  64% /
with_type.explanation: Shows disk usage with file system types

inodes.output:
Filesystem      Inodes  IUsed   IFree IUse% Mounted on
devtmpfs       1000000    500  999500    1% /dev
/dev/sda1      3276800 100000 3176800    4% /

specific.explanation: Shows disk usage for /home partition only

commands.name: du
commands.description: Estimate file space usage

h.name: human-readable
h.description: Print sizes in human readable format

s.name: summarize
s.description: Display only a total for each argument

a.name: all
a.description: Write counts for all files, not just directories

d.name: max-depth
d.description: Print total for directory only if it is N or fewer levels below command line argument

human.explanation: Shows file size in human readable format

all.explanation: Shows sizes of all files in directory

depth.explanation: Shows sizes of first-level subdirectories in /home

   CGroup: /system.slice/ssh.service
           └─1234 /usr/sbin/sshd -D
status.explanation: Shows detailed status of SSH service

enable.explanation: Enables docker to start at boot

disable.explanation: Disables mysql from starting at boot

reload.explanation: Reloads nginx configuration without dropping connections

daemon_reload.explanation: Reloads systemd after modifying service files

commands.name: journalctl

u.name: unit

n.name: lines

p.name: priority

list-boots.name: list-boots

disk-usage.name: disk-usage

vacuum-size.name: vacuum-size

vacuum-time.name: vacuum-time
vacuum-time.description: Remove journal entries older than specified time

basic.explanation: Shows all journal entries from current boot

disk_usage.output: Archived and active journals take up 500.0M in the file system.

commands.name: man

k.name: apropos

search.output:
cp (1)               - copy files and directories
scp (1)              - secure copy (remote file copy program)
rsync (1)            - faster, flexible replacement for rcp

section.explanation: Shows passwd file format (section 5) instead of passwd command

all.explanation: Shows all manual pages for printf (command and C function)

where.explanation: Shows location of ssh manual page

global_search.explanation: Searches all manual pages for 'regular expression'

troff.explanation: Creates PostScript file of ls manual page

pager.explanation: Uses less pager instead of default

l.name: long

cp (1)               - copy files and directories

rsync (1)            - faster, flexible replacement for rcp

multiple.explanation: Searches for pages containing both 'list' and 'directory'

regex.explanation: Searches for terms starting with 'zip' using regex

l.name: long

s.name: sections

basic.explanation: Same as man -f, shows brief description

wildcard.explanation: Shows descriptions for commands starting with 'zip'

regex.explanation: Shows descriptions for commands starting with 'g'

commands.name: alias
commands.description: Create or list command aliases

p.name: print
p.description: Print all defined aliases

list.output:
alias ll='ls -l'
alias la='ls -la'
alias grep='grep --color=auto'

persistent.explanation: Adds alias to bashrc for persistence

complex.command: alias update='sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade'

temporary.explanation: Aliases defined in current shell only, not in child shells

commands.name: history
commands.description: Display or manipulate the history list

d.name: delete
d.description: Delete history entry at OFFSET

a.name: append
a.description: Append new history lines to history file

n.name: read-new
n.description: Read new history lines from history file

r.name: read
r.description: Read history file and append contents to history list

w.name: write
w.description: Write current history to history file

p.name: print
p.description: Perform history expansion on args and display result

s.name: store
s.description: Append ARGS to history list as a single entry

basic.explanation: Shows command history with line numbers

append.explanation: Appends current session history to history file

last_arg.explanation: Refers to last argument of previous command

commands.name: echo
commands.description: Display a line of text

n.name: no-newline
n.description: Do not output the trailing newline

multiple.explanation: Multiple arguments are separated by spaces

commands.name: date
commands.description: Print or set the system date and time

u.name: utc
u.description: Print or set Coordinated Universal Time

R.name: rfc-email
R.description: Output date and time in RFC 5322 format

r.name: reference
r.description: Display the last modification time of FILE

s.name: set
s.description: Set time described by STRING

d.name: date
d.description: Display time described by STRING, not 'now'

from_epoch.explanation: Converts Unix timestamp to readable date

set_time.explanation: Sets system date and time (requires root)

commands.name: watch
